{{Short description|Discrimination based on physical attractiveness}} {{For|the webtoon|Lookism (manhwa)}} {{Globalize|article|USA|2name=the United States|date=December 2012}} {{Discrimination sidebar|expand-attributes=yes}} '''Lookism''' is [[prejudice]] or [[discrimination]] toward people who are considered to be physically [[unattractive]], and bases perception of all other qualities, such as intelligence and abilities, on a person’s physical appearance. It occurs in a variety of settings, including dating, social environments, and workplaces.{{Citation | title = Lookism | publisher = The Free Dictionary | url = http://www.thefreedictionary.com/lookism | access-date = September 30, 2015 }} Lookism has received less cultural attention than other forms of discrimination (such as [[racism]] and [[sexism]]) and typically does not have the legal protections that other forms often have, but it is still widespread and significantly affects people's opportunities in terms of romantic relationships, job opportunities, and other realms of life.{{cite journal | last1 = Hosoda | first1 = M. | last2 = Stone-Romero | first2 = E. F. | last3 = Coats | first3 = G.| year = 2003 | title = The effects of physical attractiveness on job-related outcomes: A meta-analysis of experimental studies | journal = Personnel Psychology | volume = 56 | issue = 2 | pages = 431–462| doi = 10.1111/j.1744-6570.2003.tb00157.x }} The same concept from the opposite angle is sometimes named [[Body privilege|pretty privilege]].{{Cite web |title='Ugly Ducklings' On How People Treated Them When They Got Hot |url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/kzg8na/ugly-ducklings-on-how-people-treated-them-when-they-got-hot |access-date=2022-10-09 |website=www.vice.com |date=7 December 2017 |language=en}} [[Physical attractiveness]] is associated with positive qualities; in contrast, physical unattractiveness is associated with negative qualities. Many people make judgments of others based on their physical appearance which influence how they respond to these people. Research on the "what is beautiful is good" stereotype shows that, overall, those who are physically attractive benefit from their good looks: physically attractive individuals are perceived more positively and physical attractiveness has a strong influence on judgement of a person's competence.{{cite journal | last1 = Eagly | first1 = Alice| last2 = Ashmore | first2 = Richard | last3 = Makhijani| first3 = Mona G.| last4 = Longo| first4 = Laura C.| year = 1991 | title = What is beautiful is good, but. | journal = Psychological Bulletin| volume = 110 | pages = 109–128 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.110.1.109}} Furthermore, research shows that on average, attractive individuals have more friends, better social skills, and more active sex lives.{{cite journal | last1 = Rhodes | first1 = Gillian | last2 = Simmons | first2 = Leigh | last3= Peters | first3= Marianne | year = 2005 | title = Attractiveness and Sexual Behavior: Does Attractiveness Enhance Mating Success?| journal = Evolution and Human Behavior| volume = 26 | issue = 2 | pages = 186–201 | doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2004.08.014}} ==Lexicology== Though the term "lookism" is of recent coinage, cultures and traditions worldwide have often warned against placing undue value on physical appearance:Louis Tietje and Steven Cresap (2005). "[https://mises.org/journals/jls/19_2/19_2_2.pdf Is Lookism Unjust? The History and Ethics of Aesthetics and Public Policy Implications]." ''Journal of Libertarian Studies'', Vol. 19 No. 2, Spring 2005, pp. 31–50
To judge by appearances is to get entangled in the Veil of [[Maya (religion)|Maya]] [in Buddhist thought] ... From ancient times until relatively recently, there was widespread worry about lookism, because the appearance of others may deceive, especially in romance, or it may be personally or politically imprudent to judge or act on appearances. Judging by appearances was prohibited by monotheistic religions ("no graven images") and criticized in ancient and medieval philosophies. [[Philosophical skepticism|Skeptics]], [[Stoics]], [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Cynics]], [[Epicureans]] and [[Scholastics]] elaborated various reasons to avoid or subordinate the role of appearances.{{Citation needed|date=July 2024}}
The term "lookism" grew in popularity in the 1970s within the [[fat acceptance movement]]. It was used in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' Magazine in 1978, which asserted that the term was coined by fat people who created the word to refer to "discrimination based on looks."John Ayto, ''20th Century Words'', Oxford: [[Oxford University Press]], 1999. {{ISBN|978-0-19-860230-9}} The word appears in several major English language dictionaries.[http://www.bartleby.com Bartleby.com] — "[http://www.bartleby.com/61/64/L0246450.html Lookism] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205050857/http://www.bartleby.com/61/64/L0246450.html |date=2008-12-05 }}". ''The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language: Fourth Edition.'' 2000. There is some overlap between the terms [[wikt:fatphobia|fatphobia]], [[wikt:teratophobia|teratophobia]], [[wikt:cacophobia|cacophobia]] and lookism.Scherer, Bee. [https://so06.tci-thaijo.org/index.php/Jiabu/article/view/220130/152257 "Buddhism and disability: toward a socially engaged Buddhist 'theology' of bodily inclusiveness"]. ''Journal of the International Association of Buddhist Universities'' (JIABU) 9.1 (2017): 26–35. In the 1990, the term "lookism" was used by Smith College{{Cite book|last1=Baird|first1=Albert Craig|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7IdLAAAAMAAJ&q=lookism+smith+college|title=Representative American Speeches|last2=Thonssen|first2=Lester|last3=Braden|first3=Waldo Warder|last4=Peterson|first4=Owen|date=1942|publisher=H.W. Wilson Company|language=en}} to warn incoming students of "lookism, a form of oppression, that involves putting too much stock in personal appearance."{{Cite web |last=Beck |first=Joan |date=1991-06-03 |title=AS PC TAKES HOLD, THE LIST OF 'ISMS' GROWS LONG AND SILLY |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1991-06-03-9102190441-story.html |access-date=2020-08-25 |website=[[Chicago Tribune]] |language=en-US}} ==Empirical support== According to [[Nancy Etcoff]], a psychologist at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]], "we face a world where lookism is one of the most pervasive but denied prejudices".[[William Safire]]. [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/27/magazine/the-way-we-live-now-8-27-00-on-language-lookism.html "The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: On Language; Lookism"], ''[[New York Times Magazine]]'', August 27, 2000. Referring to several studies, [[Angela Stalcup]] writes that "The evidence clearly indicates that not only is there a premium for prettiness in Western culture, there is also a penalty for plainness."Angela Stalcup. [http://angelastalcup.com/sample_article.pdf ''The Plainness Penalty: Lookism in Western Culture''.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707142254/http://angelastalcup.com/sample_article.pdf |date=2011-07-07 }} When discrimination on the grounds of a person's appearance turns into fear or conveyed aversion, it is referred to as cacophobia. Sometimes cacophobia may be internalized and thus directed inwards rather than towards others.{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2014/10/28/2003603118|title=Woman sues clinic after it refuses her cosmetic surgery – Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|date=28 October 2014}} Studies on newborns have found that human infants as young as 14 hours from birth prefer to look at attractive faces rather than unattractive faces.New Scientist, [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn6355-babies-prefer-to-gaze-upon-beautiful-faces/ Babies prefer to gaze upon beautiful faces]{{cite journal|title= Newborn infants prefer attractive faces|journal= Infant Behavior and Development|volume= 21|issue= 2|pages= 345–354|doi= 10.1016/S0163-6383(98)90011-X|year= 1998|last1= Slater|first1= Alan|last2= von Der Schulenburg|first2= Charlotte|last3= Brown|first3= Elizabeth|last4= Badenoch|first4= Marion|last5= Butterworth|first5= George|last6= Parsons|first6= Sonia|last7= Samuels|first7= Curtis}} The preference also extends to non-human animals such as cats.{{cite journal | pmc=2566458 | year=2008 | last1=Quinn | first1=P. C. | last2=Kelly | first2=D. J. | last3=Lee | first3=K. | last4=Pascalis | first4=O. | last5=Slater | first5=A. M. | title=Preference for attractive faces in human infants extends beyond conspecifics | journal=Developmental Science | volume=11 | issue=1 | pages=76–83 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2007.00647.x | pmid=18171370 }} These findings indicate that lookism is an innate product of how the human visual system functions.American Psychological Association, [http://www.apa.org/monitor/oct06/pretty.aspx Pretty faces: Easy on the brain?] Research by [[Dan Ariely]] found that American women exhibit a marked preference for dating taller men and that for shorter men to be judged attractive by women, they must earn substantially more money than taller men."Ariely found that a 5'4" man would need to make $229,000 more than a 6' man to have equal appeal; a 5'6" man would need $183,000 more; a 5'10" man would need $32,000 more." Lori Gottlieb (2010). ''Marry Him: The Case for Settling for Mr. Good Enough''. Penguin, {{ISBN|9781101185209}} p. 239 Some research has suggested that the "beauty premium" for a job largely depends on whether or not attractiveness could potentially enhance productivity, such as those jobs which require substantial interpersonal interaction, while jobs that do not demand this see minimal or no beauty premium.Stinebrickner, Ralph, Todd Stinebrickner, and Paul Sullivan. "Beauty, job tasks, and wages: A new conclusion about employer taste-based discrimination." Review of Economics and Statistics 101, no. 4 (2019): 602-615. Men show a strong preference for physical attractiveness over intelligence when choosing a mate, as shown in a study conducted over data from a speed dating experiment.Karbowski, A., Deja, D., & Zawisza, M. (2016). Perceived female intelligence as economic bad in partner choice. Personality and Individual Differences, 102, 217–222. doi:10.1016/j.paid.2016.07.006 In a study with 4,573 adult participants it was shown that physical attractiveness is the most valued quality in women, even when considered outside of the context of mate selection.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pewresearch.org/social-trends/2017/12/05/americans-see-different-expectations-for-men-and-women/|title = 2. Americans see different expectations for men and women|date = 5 December 2017}} Research indicates that more attractive individuals are at greater risk of being a victim of crime due to being involved in more social interaction, increasing their risk of exposure. Greater physical attractiveness can also lead individuals to be at greater risk of sexual abuse, regardless of gender.{{Cite journal|last1=Savolainen|first1=Jukka|last2=Brauer|first2=Jonathan R.|last3=Ellonen|first3=Noora|date=2020-01-01|title=Beauty is in the eye of the offender: Physical attractiveness and adolescent victimization|journal=Journal of Criminal Justice|language=en|volume=66|pages=101652|doi=10.1016/j.jcrimjus.2019.101652|issn=0047-2352|doi-access=free}} Some writers have examined this phenomenon among [[gay men]]. According to the block quote on page 117 of a 2004 work by Todd Morrison,{{cite book |author=Morrison, Todd |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v6suAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA117 |title=Eclectic Views on Gay Male Pornography: Pornucopia |date=2004 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781317972297 |page=117 |access-date=April 30, 2017}} author [[Michelangelo Signorile]] (in a 1997 overview of contemporary trends in the gay male community) described "body fascism" as
the setting of a rigid set of standards of physical beauty that pressures everyone within a particular group to conform to them. Any person who doesn't meet those very specific standards is deemed physically unattractive and sexually undesirable. In a culture in which the physical body is held in such high esteem and given such power, body fascism then not only deems those who don't or can't conform to be sexually less desirable, but in the extreme – sometimes dubbed "looksism" – also deems an individual completely worthless ''as a person,'' based solely on his exterior. In this sense it is not unlike racism or sexism or homophobia itself. ... (p. 28)Morrison, Todd Eclectic Views on Gay Male Pornography: Pornucopia, Volume 47, Psychology Press, {{ISBN|9781560232919}}
An October 2020 paper from University of Memphis{{Cite journal |last1=Jobu Babin |first1=J. |last2=Hussey |first2=Andrew |last3=Nikolsko-Rzhevskyy |first3=Alex |last4=Taylor |first4=David A. |date=2020-10-01 |title=Beauty Premiums Among Academics |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0272775719307538 |journal=Economics of Education Review |language=en |volume=78 |pages=102019 |doi=10.1016/j.econedurev.2020.102019 |issn=0272-7757 |s2cid=224846380}} examined the effects of instructors' attractiveness on student evaluations of their teaching.{{Cite web |last1=Warhurst |first1=Christopher |last2=Nickson |first2=Dennis |date=16 October 2020 |title=Lookism: beauty still trumps brains in too many workplaces |url=http://theconversation.com/lookism-beauty-still-trumps-brains-in-too-many-workplaces-148278 |access-date=2020-10-19 |website=The Conversation |language=en}} A 2021 study on the effects of the wearing of facemasks in the hospitality industry corroborated existing findings{{Cite journal |last1=Kim |first1=W. |last2=Ok |first2=C. |date=2010-01-13 |title=Customer Orientation of Service Employees and Rapport: Influences On Service-Outcome Variables in Full-Service Restaurants |url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1096348009344234 |journal=Journal of Hospitality & Tourism Research |language=en |volume=34 |pages=34–55 |doi=10.1177/1096348009344234 |s2cid=154408619}} on the correlation between perceived physical attractiveness of frontline workers and customer satisfaction. The study found that the wearing of facemasks by hospitality employees minimized the effects of their actual attractiveness on reported customer satisfaction, leveling off the playing field between average-looking employees and attractive-looking employees.{{Cite journal |last1=Wu |first1=G. |last2=Liang |first2=L. |last3=Gursoy |first3=D. |date=2021-08-01 |title=Effects of the new COVID-19 normal on customer satisfaction: Can facemasks level off the playing field between average-looking and attractive-looking employees? |journal=International Journal of Hospitality Management |language=en |volume=97 |page=102996 |doi=10.1016/j.ijhm.2021.102996 |pmc=9756379 |pmid=36540069 |s2cid=236244843 |doi-access=free}} A 2023 study found that attractive victims of [[intimate partner violence]] are viewed as being more credible compared to less attractive victims.{{Cite journal |last=Hall |first=Maisie |last2=Debowska |first2=Agata |last3=K Hales |first3=George |date=July 2024 |title=The Effect of Victim Attractiveness and Type of Abuse Suffered on Attributions of Victim Blame and Credibility in Intimate Partner Violence: A Vignette-Based Online Experiment |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36624627/ |journal=Violence Against Women |volume=30 |issue=9 |pages=2396–2416 |doi=10.1177/10778012221150272 |issn=1552-8448 |pmid=36624627}} ==In politics== Lookism has been an issue in politics for centuries, with a long tradition in the United Kingdom of "mercilessly exaggerat[ing]" the physical flaws of politicians in newspaper cartoons.Jones, Johnathan (2012). "[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/jan/10/too-ugly-for-politics-ed-miliband Can you be too ugly for politics?]", ''The Guardian'' 10 January 2012; accessed 19 October 2013 In the [[1960 United States presidential election#Debates|1960 US Presidential race between John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon]], it was often believed that Kennedy's more conventionally handsome appearance contributed to his winning more approval in their first televised debate than Nixon's more unconventionally handsome appearance,{{cite web |url=http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=kennedy-nixon |title=THE KENNEDY-NIXON PRESIDENTIAL DEBATES, 1960 – The Museum of Broadcast Communications |publisher=The Museum of Broadcast Communications (MBC) |access-date=2010-10-08 |archive-date=2010-08-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821064309/http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=kennedy-nixon |url-status=dead }} but some researchers have challenged this widespread idea and argued that Kennedy's appearance had little or no influence.{{Cite journal|title=The myth of viewer-listener disagreement in the first Kennedy-Nixon debate|journal=Central States Speech Journal|volume=38|pages=16–27|year= 1987 |doi=10.1080/10510978709368226|last1=Vancil|first1=David L.|last2=Pendell|first2=Sue D.}} More broadly, research in countries such as Germany,{{Cite journal|last1=Jäckle|first1=Sebastian|last2=Metz|first2=Thomas|date=August 2017|title=Beauty Contest Revisited: The Effects of Perceived Attractiveness, Competence, and Likability on the Electoral Success of German MPs: BEAUTY CONTEST REVISITED|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/polp.12209|journal=Politics & Policy|language=en|volume=45|issue=4|pages=495–534|doi=10.1111/polp.12209}} Canada,{{Cite journal|title=APA PsycNet|url=https://doi.apa.org/doiLanding?doi=10.1037/h0081881|access-date=2021-01-05|journal=Canadian Journal of Behavioural Science Revue Canadienne des Sciences du Comportement|year = 1974|volume = 6|issue = 4|pages = 352–356|doi=10.1037/h0081881|last1 = Efrain|first1 = Michael G.}} the United States,{{Cite journal|last1=Lev-On|first1=Azi|last2=Waismel-Manor|first2=Israel|date=2016-12-01|title=Looks That Matter: The Effect of Physical Attractiveness in Low- and High-Information Elections|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/0002764216676249|journal=American Behavioral Scientist|language=en|volume=60|issue=14|pages=1756–1771|doi=10.1177/0002764216676249|s2cid=151694489|issn=0002-7642}} and the United Kingdom{{Cite journal|last1=Milazzo|first1=Caitlin|last2=Mattes|first2=Kyle|date=2015-06-01|title=Looking Good For Election Day: Does Attractiveness Predict Electoral Success in Britain?|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1111/1467-856X.12074|journal=The British Journal of Politics and International Relations|volume=18|pages=161–178|language=en|doi=10.1111/1467-856x.12074|s2cid=145138419|issn=1467-856X}} has found that more attractive candidates benefit from their appearance by getting more votes in elections, and by being more often forgiven for scandals.{{Cite journal|last1=Stockemer|first1=Daniel|last2=Praino|first2=Rodrigo|date=2019-09-01|title=The Good, the Bad and the Ugly: Do Attractive Politicians Get a 'Break' When They are Involved in Scandals?|journal=Political Behavior|language=en|volume=41|issue=3|pages=747–767|doi=10.1007/s11109-018-9469-1|issn=1573-6687|doi-access=free}} In terms of vote choice, at least, the effect of lookism is not even across all contexts. Rather, it appears to primarily matter in cases where voters have [[Low information voter|low-information elections]] where voters may have little other to base their vote on (such as non-partisan elections with little media coverage), [[First-past-the-post voting|first-past-the-post]] elections where voters chose a single candidate,{{Cite journal|last1=Stockemer|first1=Daniel|last2=Praino|first2=Rodrigo|date=2017-05-01|title=Physical attractiveness, voter heuristics and electoral systems: The role of candidate attractiveness under different institutional designs|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/1369148116687533|journal=The British Journal of Politics and International Relations|language=en|volume=19|issue=2|pages=336–352|doi=10.1177/1369148116687533|s2cid=157389662|issn=1369-1481}} and in elections that are candidate-centered within a weak [[party system]].{{Cite journal|last1=Wigginton|first1=Michael|last2=Stockemer|first2=Daniel|date=2021-04-01|title=The limits of the attractiveness premium in elections|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0261379420301529|journal=Electoral Studies|language=en|volume=70|pages=102274|doi=10.1016/j.electstud.2020.102274|s2cid=233073202|issn=0261-3794}} There are several variables that might contribute to the objectification of masculinity and femininity in politics. Scholar Charlotte Hooper argued that "gender intersects with other social divisions such as class, race and sexuality to produce complex hierarchies of (gendered) identities".{{cite journal|last=Hooper|first=Charlotte|title=Masculinities, IR and the 'gender variable': a cost-benefit analysis for (sympathetic) gender sceptics|journal=Review of International Studies|year=1999|volume=25|issue=3|pages=475–480|doi=10.1017/s0260210599004751|doi-broken-date=1 November 2024 |s2cid=145630038 }} Hooper argues that institutional practices, such as military combat in war, have greatly defined what it means to be a man. Furthermore, the symbolic dimension, which includes sports, media, current affairs, etc. has "disseminate[d] a wealth of popular iconography which links Western masculinities to the wider world beyond the borders of the state".{{cite journal|last=Hooper|first=Charlotte|title=Masculinities, IR and the 'gender variable': a cost-benefit analysis for (sympathetic) gender sceptics|journal=Review of International Studies|year=1999|volume=25|issue=3|pages=475–580|doi=10.1017/s0260210599004751|doi-broken-date=1 November 2024 |s2cid=145630038 }} This is where the ideology of lookism is firmly entrenched according to Hooper. Similarly, Laura Shepherd suggests that men are required to fit into the "matrix of intelligibility"{{cite book|last=Shepherd|first=Laura J.|title=Sex or Gender? Bodies in World Politics and Why Gender Matters|year=2010|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|chapter=1}} by acting a certain way, dressing a certain way, and have a mentality that is devoid of emotion or anything effeminate; if they are successful in becoming the ultimate "man's man" then they are virtually untouchable. However, others have suggested that there is only an explicit interest in the analysis of masculinity within this political sphere, it will be impossible to develop a reliable analysis of femininity within this same sphere.{{cite journal|last=Enloe|first=Cynthia|title='Gender' is not enough: the need for a feminist consciousness|journal=International Affairs |page=97}} Drawing examples from [[Madeleine Albright]]'s TED talk in 2010, "On Being a Woman and Diplomat", Albright expressed her frustrations with how her male colleagues and media commentators would pick apart her appearance. Being the first female Secretary of State for the United States, Albright was in the spotlight on the domestic and international stage; everything from her age, weight, hairstyle, and choice of dress were scrutinized; yet ironically, the policy positions she believed to be her most important accomplishments (initiation of the G7, attempts to promote gender equality, etc.) were hardly taken into account.{{cite web|last=Albright|first=Madeleine|title=On Being a Woman and a Diplomat|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/madeleine_albright_on_being_a_woman_and_a_diplomat.html|work=TED Talk|publisher=TEDwomen}} The fact that Albright's general appearance did not fit into the narrow category of "attractive" made it even more difficult for her to navigate the space between being a woman and a diplomat. Albright is not the only woman in a position of power, or otherwise, that has been discriminated against because of her appearance. An article published in ''The Washington Post'' in 2005 labeled Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] as a "[[dominatrix]]" when she stepped out in knee-high black-heeled boots during a visit to Wiesbaden Military Base in Germany.{{cite news|last=Givhan|first=Robin|title=Condoleezza Rice's Commanding Clothes|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 25, 2005}} Although the article was meant to give credit to Rice for "challeng[ing] expectations and assumptions", some{{who|date=October 2013}} argue that the article gave her a hyper-sexualized image, and further removed the audience from focusing on the purpose of her visit to the military place. Similarly, media commentators have often chosen to report on Hillary Clinton's "man suits" and Julia Gillard's short hairstyle, instead of focusing on these women's professional accomplishments.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} [[Sarah Palin]], former governor of Alaska and 2008 Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, was the subject of much media attention due to her conventionally attractive appearance,Frick, Ali (2008). [http://thinkprogress.org/politics/2008/09/05/28702/cnbc-host-praises-palin-for-putting-a-skirt-on-i-want-her-laying-next-to-me-in-bed/ CNBC host praises Palin for 'putting a skirt on': 'I want her laying next to me in bed.'], accessed 19 October 2013 with Palin suggesting that the focus on her appearance ignored her professional and policy accomplishments.Orr, Jimmy (2009). In the 2016 presidential race, considerable mention was made of Donald Trump's choice of hairstyle, skin tone, and dress sense. [http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/The-Vote/2009/1117/is-sarah-palin-newsweek-cover-sexist-palin-says-yesIs Sarah Palin Newsweek cover sexist? Palin says yes] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200208130401/https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/The-Vote/2009/1117/is-sarah-palin-newsweek-cover-sexist-palin-says-yesIs |date=2020-02-08 }}, accessed 19 October 2013 ==Related forms of prejudice== Lookism has received scholarly attention both from a [[cultural studies]] and an [[economics]] perspective. In the former context, lookism relates to preconceived notions of [[beauty]] and cultural [[stereotyping]] based on appearance as well as [[gender role]]s and expectations. Important economic considerations include the question of income gaps based on looks, as well as increased or decreased productivity from workers considered beautiful or ugly by their co-workers. Due to this, new problems arise that are tied to other social issues such as racism and ageism (young over old). The idea of beauty is also linked directly to social class because people who have more free time and money have the ability to work on their appearance. Weight is also linked to social class because poorer people who are overweight, in First World countries, do not have the exercise equipment or the healthy food choices that wealthier people do. Judging people on the basis of attractiveness decreases a person's self-esteem leading to a negative self-image.{{cite web |last1=Grollman |first1=Dr. Eric Anthony |title=Prejudice And Attraction: Is Beauty Really In The Beholder's Eye? |url=http://kinseyconfidential.org/prejudice-attraction-beauty-beholders-eye/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180915052040/https://kinseyconfidential.org/prejudice-attraction-beauty-beholders-eye/ |archive-date=15 September 2018 |access-date=26 October 2015 |website=Kinsey Confidential}} == Ethics == In the article "Is Lookism Unjust?", [[Louis Tietje]] and [[Steven Cresap]] discuss when discrimination based on looks can legitimately be described as unjust.Louis Tietje and Steven Cresap. (2005). "[https://www.mises.org/journals/jls/19_2/19_2_2.pdf Is Lookism Unjust?: The Ethics of Aesthetics and Public Policy Implications]". ''[[Journal of Libertarian Studies]]'' 19 (2): 31–50. Tietje and Cresap quote evidence that suggests there exists "a 7–to–9 percent 'penalty' for being in the lowest 9 percent of looks among all workers and a 5 percent 'premium' for being in the top 33 percent". While accepting that the evidence indicates that such discrimination does occur, the authors argue that it has been pervasive throughout history and that judgments of aesthetics appear to be a biological adaptation (rather than culturally conditioned) to aid reproduction, survival, and social interaction, allowing people to determine viable mates (level of attractiveness being indicative of health) and the status of others as "friend or enemy, threat or opportunity". The authors also argue that if physical attractiveness can improve a company's success, then awarding people for it is justifiable [from a purely profit motivated POV], as the trait is thus relevant to the job and discrimination only occurs when irrelevant traits are used. In addition, the authors question the practicality of both redressing any injustices based on lookism and of determining whether such injustices have in fact occurred. Thus the authors conclude that there can be no clear model of injustice in such discrimination, nor would legislation to address it be practicable – "We do not see how any policy interventions to redress beauty discrimination can be justified." [[Nancy Etcoff]], author of ''Survival of the Prettiest'', argues that human preference for attractiveness is rooted in evolutionary instinct and that trying to prevent it from influencing people would be "telling them to stop enjoying food or sex or novelty or love" and thus argues that "being beautiful and being prized for it is not a social evil."Etcoff, Nancy. Survival of the prettiest: The science of beauty.
